lexicon_requests.reason: Only psalm titled 'tehillah' - need semantic distinction from other praise terms
Elevation metaphor - specific semantic range of this praise verb
Pual form - passive praise construction, theological implications
Investigation/fathoming - philosophical concept of divine comprehensibility
Generational transmission terminology - temporal vs. genealogical emphasis
First element of triple glory construct - specific nuance vs. כבוד/הוד
Strength/intensity of awesome deeds - rare substantival usage
Memorial vs. memory - cultic/liturgical technical term
Gushing/pouring forth - vigorous liquid metaphor for praise
Long-nose idiom - ANE background and theological development
Faithful ones vs. works distinction - covenant community terminology
Truth/sincerity qualifier for prayer - moral epistemology
All flesh vs. all people - specific anthropological scope

concordance_requests.purpose: Compare tehillah usage patterns vs. other praise terms
Universal dependence imagery - eyes of all looking expectantly
Temporal eternity formula - obsessive usage pattern
Divine goodness to all creation - universalism theology
Sons of humanity - universal address patterns

figurative_requests.reason: Investigation metaphor for divine comprehension - rare epistemological imagery | Vehicle: investigation | Related terms: investigate, search, searching, examine, examining, probe, probing
Pouring forth goodness - vivid liquid metaphor for divine attribute | Vehicle: pour | Related terms: pour, pours, pouring, gush, gushes, gushing, flow, flows, flowing
Physical support imagery - bodies falling and bending as human condition | Vehicle: fallen | Related terms: fall, falls, falling, stumble, stumbles, stumbling
Bent/bowed physical imagery - bodily metaphor for human condition | Vehicle: bent | Related terms: bow, bows, bowed, bowing, crouch, crouched
Eyes as universal dependence - striking personification of all creation | Vehicle: expectation | Related terms: expect, expects, expecting, hope, hopes, hoping, wait, waiting
Open hand gesture - generous divine action metaphor | Vehicle: opening | Related terms: open, opens, opened

commentary_requests.reason: Unique tehillah title - how do commentators explain this psalm's special status?
Daily blessing commitment - traditional understanding of liturgical obligation
Divine transcendence claim - how commentators handle epistemological limits
Generational transmission focus - classical interpretation of works vs. character
Triple glory construction - how commentators parse the dense Hebrew syntax
Textual variant issue - traditional manuscript and interpretive approaches
Memorial terminology - liturgical vs. personal memory in classical exegesis
Selective divine attribute quotation - why omit 'truth and faithfulness'?
Universal divine goodness - how commentators handle radical inclusivity
Works vs. faithful distinction - covenant particularism within universalism
Royal proclamation theme - kingship theology in praise context
Mission to humanity - universal proclamation purpose
Eternal kingship formula - ANE background and theological adaptation
Physical care imagery - literal vs. metaphorical interpretation of disability
Eyes of all creation - how commentators handle universal personification
Divine satisfaction provision - abundance vs. necessity theology
Character-action integration - how divine ways reflect divine nature
Qualified divine accessibility - what constitutes calling 'in truth'?
God-fearer privileges - covenant benefits within universal framework
Theodicy tension - destroying wicked vs. universal goodness
All flesh conclusion - universal summons and inclusio completion

ugaritic_parallels.analysis: This shared formula for celebrating divine kingship demonstrates a common liturgical and royal vocab...

macro_questions: How does the complete acrostic structure function theologically beyond literary artistry, and what does it suggest about comprehensive praise?
What is the significance of the divine epithet progression from 'my God the King' to 'YHWH' throughout the psalm?
How does the Ugaritic parallel in v. 13 illuminate the relationship between Israelite and broader ANE royal theology?
What is the theological significance of the movement from God's incomprehensible greatness (v. 3) to intimate care (vv. 15-16)?
How does the 'eyes of all' imagery (v. 15) function within the broader creation theology of the psalm?
What is the relationship between the generational transmission theme (vv. 4, 13) and the eternal praise framework?
How does the theodicy element (v. 20) fit into the comprehensive praise structure without creating tension?
What is the significance of the progression from 'works' and 'mighty acts' to specific care for the fallen and hungry?
How does this psalm function as a theological summary of praise literature in relation to other Hallel psalms?
What is the relationship between covenant (faithful ones, those who fear him) and creation (all flesh, all his works) in the psalm's theological vision?
micro_questions: Why is this the only psalm titled 'תְּהִלָּה' when this word gives the whole psalter its name?
What is the theological significance of selectively quoting the Exodus 34:6 formula while omitting 'truth and faithfulness'?
How does the LXX addition in v13a ('Faithful is the LORD in his words...') illuminate early interpretive traditions?
Is the triple construct chain 'הֲדַר כְּבוֹד הוֹדֶךָ' standard Hebrew syntax or innovative poetic accumulation?
How do we reconcile 'good to all' (v9) with 'destroys all the wicked' (v20) - is this theological tension intentional?
Why does the psalm use 'כׇּל־בָּשָׂר' (all flesh) in the conclusion rather than 'all people' or 'all creation'?
What is the difference between יוֹדוּךָ (praise from all works) and יְבָרְכוּכָה (bless from faithful ones) in v10?
Does the 'עֵינֵי־כֹל' (eyes of all) image include non-animate creation having metaphorical 'eyes'?
